_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: Driver accidentally opened valve releasing residual product in truck piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC operates an ethanol fuel production plant located in the city of Stockton, in San

Joaquin County, California. As a requirement of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP)

Program and Clean Air Act Amendments 112® Accidental Release of Hazardous Air Substances program,

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has completed a risk management plan (RMP) for chemicals stored on?]site

above RMP reporting thresholds. Regulated chemicals at Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC include isopentane and

pentane (each exceed 10,000 pound threshold) and aqueous ammonia (exceeds 20,000 pound threshold).



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the

environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol production process, specifically aqueous

ammonia and isopentane and pentane (constituents of the natural gasoline used as a denaturant). The

ammonia is used for pH control directly in the process feed mixture to fermentation. The denaturant is

added to ethanol to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption. It is the policy of Pacific Ethanol

Stockton, LLC to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws. In the event of an emergency,

including an accidental release of toxics and flammables, it is the policy of Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC to

notify the Stockton Fire Department and the San Joaquin County Office of Emergency Services and evacuate

all employees at the facility.



Regulated Substances Handled

The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and a process by?]product known as wet distillers' grain

with solubles, which is used as a livestock feed. Aqueous ammonia is stored on?]site and used in the ethanol

production process for pH control. The maximum amount of aqueous ammonia stored is approximately

34,200 pounds (20?]30 percent ammonia in solution). The fuel ethanol production

process requires use of a

denaturant (natural gasoline) which may contain approximately 10 percent pentane and approximately 7

percent isopentane, both RMP?]regulated substances. The maximum amount of denaturant on?]site is

approximately 437,000 pounds (total pentane approximately 44,000 pounds; total isopentane approximately

31,000 pounds). The natural gasoline is stored in an above ground tank as a liquid and is mixed with the fuel

ethanol in the final stage of production; this tank is located in the facility tank farm area, which includes a

secondary containment dike. Unleaded fuel may also be used as a denaturant in place of natural gasoline

and does not contain any regulated constituents above the threshold quantity. Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC

has evaluated the worst?]case and alternative case scenarios as they relate to the regulated substances. An

Emergency Response Program (included in the facility Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP)) was implemented

at start?]up. Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities, is an active member of the Port of Stockton Foam Consortium, has sponsored and hosted emergency responder training. 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has complied with the EPA requirements

under 40 CFR Part 68 and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, as well as California

regulations at CCR Title 8, Section 5189 and CCR Title 19 D?]2, Chapter 4.5. Process safety information, safe

work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and

maintenance procedures are documented on?]site as part of the facility PSM/RMP Prevention Program.

Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, management of change, pre?]startup safety

reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis as outlined in the PSM/RMP Prevention

Program. Audits of the

overall RMP and Prevention Program are conducted on a regular basis to assure

compliance with EPA regulations.



Emergency Response Program

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has developed their own written emergency response plan (included in the

ICP). This plan includes actions to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances, actions to inform

the public and local agencies responding to accidental releases and emergency health care information.

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC routinely conducts employee training on the ICP and evaluates

the plan for necessary revisions following each incident.



2013 Hazard & Operability PHAs Replacing 2008 What If PHAs

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC completed a new Hazard and Operability

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the aqueous ammonia and flammables

processes on August 12 2013. Recommendations to improve

facility safety were identified during the PHA process, and a timeline is being

developed to track the recommendations to completion within 6 months. A complete summary

of the PHA process and recommendation tracking progress is maintained at the

facility.



Five-Year Accident History

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has not had any accidental releases from covered processes that

resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries,

evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The facility started

operations in fall of 2008.
